content: The Act is titled the "National Museum of Industrial History Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purpose section. The Congress finds that the transition of the United States from agricultural to industrial to post-industrial society embodies its spirit. It is crucial for people to learn about this history and preserve it for future generations by exhibiting key structures and artifacts in an educational museum. The former Bethlehem Steel Plant, proposed site of the National Museum of Industrial History, holds significant relevance in preserving the history of industrialization. Key events such as the beginnings of the plant in the 1850s, the first commercial zinc production in 1853, Frederick W. Taylor's time and motion studies, and the birth of the modern American defense industry in 1887 are associated with this site. The Bethlehem Steel Plant produced armor plate for battleships and perfected high-speed tool steel. In 1908, it became the first rolling mill in the US to produce large wide-flange steel beams. The site contains the oldest remains of bessemer steel production in the US. The purpose of the Act is to establish an interpretive center and museum in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania to protect historical resources related to industrialization and interpret its impact on US history. The Act aims to establish an Industrial History Interpretive Center and Museum in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania to preserve historical resources related to industrialization and its impact on US history. The Secretary of the Interior will seek an agreement to provide federal financial assistance for an interpretive center and museum at the former Bethlehem Steel Plant Site in Pennsylvania. The purpose is to preserve and display historical resources related to industrialization in the US and promote regional historical and cultural resources. The federal financial assistance for the interpretive center and museum at the former Bethlehem Steel Plant Site in Pennsylvania is limited to specific activities such as facilities construction, acquiring technology for historical information presentation, and program development. Financial assistance for the interpretive center and museum at the former Bethlehem Steel Plant Site in Pennsylvania is limited to activities like curriculum design, development, and staff salaries for authorized activities. Prohibited expenses include acquiring items for the museum's collection, administrative expenses, technology for administrative purposes, and staff salaries for administrative tasks. The Secretary will require non-Federal sources to match funds provided for authorized activities, not exceeding $25,000,000 annually. Payments will be made within 30 days of the agreement. The Secretary will make five payments under the agreement, with annual reports to Congress describing the interpretive center's progress, funded projects, and available funds. Authorization of appropriations is provided. Authorized $25,000,000 for the Secretary to carry out this section, with funds remaining available until expended.
